name: pyrinoline
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1432
Reason: 1,3-Dimethylpyrrolidine, also known as pyrinoline, has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components: (1) The basic unit for comparison is piperidine, which has a melting point of approximately 100 degrees Celsius. (2) The methyl groups (–CH3) add approximately +10 degrees Celsius due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity. (3) The pyrrole ring (C1=CC(C=C1)=C) introduces a significant increase due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and the rigidity it brings, estimated at around +30 degrees Celsius. (4) The additional functional groups, such as the methoxy group (–O–), can contribute to the melting point, but their exact impact is difficult to quantify without experimental data or detailed computational studies.
